awd_titl_txt: TWC SBE: Medium: Collaborative: Building a Privacy-Preserving Social Networking Platform from a Technological and Sociological Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Social networks provide many benefits, but also give rise to serious concerns regarding privacy. Indeed, since privacy protections are not intrinsically incorporated into the underlying technological framework, user data is still accessible to the social network and is open to misuse. While there have been efforts to incorporate privacy into social networks, existing solutions are not sufficiently lightweight, transparent, and functional, and therefore have achieved only limited adoption. This project develops a privacy-preserving social network (Trusted-Space) where user data are protected from the social network itself, other social network users, and advertisers. The project synthesizes solutions from a technological and sociological perspective to ensure that all of the required functionalities for both users and advertisers to participate effectively in the social network are available. The project develops compact data representations and usability driven functionalities that are privacy-preserving. The project also evaluates people's expectations about the implications of their own actions on their privacy and the future behavior of the algorithms, towards creating a simple, transparent, and predictable environment to facilitate widespread adoption. 

Since social networks permeate modern life, the project will have significant impact through enabling the incorporation of usable privacy technology into the social network fabric. The project also cultivates the integration of research and education, by providing opportunities for research to undergraduates and graduates, while increasing the awareness of privacy issues among the general public through outreach activities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Social networks provide many benefits, but also give rise to serious concerns regarding privacy. Indeed, since privacy protections are not intrinsically incorporated into the underlying technological framework, user data is still accessible to the social network and is open to misuse. While there have been efforts to incorporate privacy into social networks, existing solutions are not sufficiently lightweight, transparent, and functional, and therefore have achieved only limited adoption. This project studied the technical challenges to building a scalable and usable privacy-preserving social networking platform.

Through the span of the project, we have created several privacy-preserving solutions with varying tradeoffs of privacy and efficiency to perform friend recommendation in an integrated partnership environment where one well-established social network provides recommendation services to another social network which may not have sufficient resources. Solutions for privacy-preserving friend search have also been developed.

Since the problem of privacy and security threats arising from images uploaded onto popular social media and content sharing websites is prevalent now more than ever, a real-time image privacy alert tool has been developed. The tool utilizes convolutional neural networks and takes into account privacy concerns of multiple objects depicted on the same photo to identify sensitive and non-sensitive image content. Inspired by differential privacy, we have defined the notion of ϵ-Object Indistinguishability for all predefined sensitive objects in a video, and have proposed a video sanitization technique that randomly generates utility-driven synthetic videos with indistinguishable objects. We have also developed a novel defensive approach that leverages deep learning techniques to automatically detect data poisoning attacks against Facial authentication.

Access control is particularly important for Social Networks to ensure privacy and security of the sensitive data stored within it. Several solutions have been developed for automatic access control management including solutions for policy specification, enforcement, maintenance, analysis, and deployment.

Solutions have also been developed for several related problems such as secure linkage which is necessary when data is vertically partitioned to enable joint analysis, secure information retrieval, and techniques for the private identification of anomalies. Synthetic data generation techniques based on random decision trees have been developed to generate synthetic data that is similar in character to the underlying data while preserving privacy. As such, the solutions developed are broadly applicable to a variety of applications and areas.

From the perspective of intellectual merit, our research has advanced the state of the art in methods and techniques to ensure privacy, security, and usability for social networking platforms and improved the scientific understanding of privacy in this context. Given the fundamental prevalence of social networking, the tools and techniques developed in the project will continue to have a transformative effect on the community. The project has also resulted in significant broader impact through the broad applicability of the developed solutions, student training initiatives, and public dissemination. Specifically, several students have been trained through the project, and education and dissemination activities have been carried out at both the undergraduate and graduate level. Privacy issues regarding online social networks were discussed in science and technology summer camps, and at conference keynotes, and published in peer-reviewed journal articles and conference papers, thus providing a pathway through which the work could be disseminated to the public.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Jaideep Vaidya
